title: Estimation of the spatio-temporal anisotropy — estiStAni
text: empVgm empirical spatio-temporal variogram. interval search interval optimisation spatio-temporal anisotropy parameter method character string determining method used (one linear, range, vgm metric, see details) spatialVgm spatial variogram definition call vgm. model optimised based pure spatial values empVgm. temporalVgm temporal variogram definition call vgm. model optimised based pure temporal values empVgm. s.range spatial cutoff value applied empirical variogram empVgm. t.range temporal cutoff value applied empirical variogram empVgm.

title: Estimation of the spatio-temporal anisotropy — estiStAni
text: linear linear model fitted pure spatial gamma values based spatial distances. optimal scaling searched stretch temporal distances linear model explains best pure temporal gamma values. assumes (average) linear relationship distance gamma, hence advisable use pairs pure spatial (pure temporal) distance gamma value show considerable increase (.e. drop values beyond range setting values s.range t.range). range spatial temporal variogram model fitted pure spatial temporal gamma values respectively. spatio-temporal anisotropy estimate ratio spatial range temporal range. vgm spatial variogram model fitted pure spatial gamma values. optimal scaling used stretch temporal distances spatial variogram model explains best pure temporal gamma values. metric metric spatio-temporal variogram model fitted joint component according defined spatial variogram spatialVgm. starting value stAni mean interval parameter (see vgmST metric variogram definition). spatio-temporal anisotropy estimated spatio-temporal variogram returned. Note parameter interval used set starting value. Hence, estimate might exceed given interval.

title: Fit a spatio-temporal sample variogram to a sample variogram — fit.StVariogram
code: fit.StVariogram(object, model, ...,  method = "L-BFGS-B",   lower, upper, fit.method = 6, stAni=NA, wles)

title: Fit a spatio-temporal sample variogram to a sample variogram — fit.StVariogram
text: object spatio-temporal sample variogram. Typically output variogramST model desired spatio-temporal model defined vgmST. ... arguments passed optim. extractParNames provides parameter structure spatio-temporal variogram models help provide sensible upper lower limits. lower Lower limits used optim. missing, smallest well defined values used (mostly near 0). upper Upper limits used optim. missing, largest well defined values used (mostly Inf). method fit method, pass optim fit.method integer 0 13 determine fitting routine (.e. weighting squared residuals LSE). Values 0 6 correspond pure spatial version (see fit.variogram). See details section meaning values (partly experimental). stAni spatio-temporal anisotropy used weighting. Might missing desired spatio-temporal variogram model contain spatio-temporal anisotropy parameter (might cause bad convergence behaviour). default NA understood identity (1 temporal unit = 1 spatial unit). cases valid assumption, warning issued. wles missing; backwards compatibility, wles = TRUE corresponds fit.method = 1 wles = FALSE corresponds fit.method = 6.

title: Fit a spatio-temporal sample variogram to a sample variogram — fit.StVariogram
text: following list summarizes meaning fit.method argument essential weighting squared residuals least-squares estimation. Please note, weights based models gamma value might fail converge properly due dependence weights variogram estimate: fit.method = 0 fitting, however MSE provided variogram model sample variogram surface calculated. fit.method = 1 Number pairs spatio-temporal bin: \(N_j\) fit.method = 2 Number pairs spatio-temporal bin divided square current variogram model's value: \(N_j/\gamma(h_j, u_j)^2\) fit.method = 3 fit.method = 1 compatibility fit.variogram well evaluated R. fit.method = 4 fit.method = 2 compatibility fit.variogram well evaluated R. fit.method = 5 Reserved REML compatibility fit.variogram, yet implemented. fit.method = 6 weights. fit.method = 7 Number pairs spatio-temporal bin divided square bin's metric distance. stAni specified, model's  parameter used calculate metric distance across space time: \(N_j/(h_j^2 + {\rm stAni}^2\cdot u_j^2)\) fit.method = 8 Number pairs spatio-temporal bin divided square bin's spatial distance. \(N_j/h_j^2\). Note 0 distances replaced smallest non-zero distances avoid division zero. fit.method = 9 Number pairs spatio-temporal bin divided square bin's temporal distance. \(N_j/u_j^2\). Note 0 distances replaced smallest non-zero distances avoid division zero. fit.method = 10 Reciprocal square current variogram model's value: \(1/\gamma(h_j,u_j)^2\) fit.method = 11 Reciprocal square bin's metric distance. stAni specified, model's  parameter used calculate metric distance across space time: \(1/(h_j^2 + {\rm stAni}^2\cdot u_j^2)\) fit.method = 12 Reciprocal square bin's spatial distance. \(1/h_j^2\). Note 0 distances replaced smallest non-zero distances avoid division zero. fit.method = 13 Reciprocal square bin's temporal distance. \(1/u_j^2\). Note 0 distances replaced smallest non-zero distances avoid division zero. See also Table 4.2 gstat manual original spatial version.

title: Fit a spatio-temporal sample variogram to a sample variogram — fit.StVariogram
text: Returns spatio-temporal variogram model, S3 class StVariogramModel. carries temporal spatial unit attributes "temporal unit" "spatial unit" order allow krigeST adjust different units. units obtained provided empirical variogram. attributes optim output "optim.output" always weighted mean squared error "MSE".

title: Fit a spatio-temporal sample variogram to a sample variogram — fit.StVariogram
text: Benedikt Graeler

title: Fit a spatio-temporal sample variogram to a sample variogram — fit.StVariogram
code: # separable model: spatial and temporal sill will be ignored # and kept constant at 1-nugget respectively. A joint sill is used. if (FALSE) { separableModel <- vgmST("separable",                          method = "Nelder-Mead", # no lower & upper needed                         space=vgm(0.9,"Exp", 123, 0.1),                         time =vgm(0.9,"Exp", 2.9, 0.1),                         sill=100)  data(vv) separableModel <- fit.StVariogram(vv, separableModel,                                   method="L-BFGS-B",                                   lower=c(10,0,0.01,0,1),                                   upper=c(500,1,20,1,200)) plot(vv, separableModel) } # dontrun

title: Fit a Linear Model of Coregionalization to a Multivariable Sample Variogram — fit.lmc
text: function use iterative procedure proposed M. Goulard M. Voltz (Math. Geol., 24(3): 269-286; reproduced Goovaerts' 1997 book) uses simply two steps: first, variogram model fitted direct cross variogram; next partial sill coefficient matrices approached least squares sense closest positive definite matrices (setting negative eigenvalues zero). argument correct.diagonal introduced experience: zeroing negative eigenvalues fitting positive definite partial sill matrices, apparently still perfect correlation may result, leading singular cokriging/cosimulation matrices. someone knows elegant way get around , please let know.

text: fitting range(s) part job function, results may well depend starting values, given argument model, generally case non-linear regression problems. function uses internal C code, uses Levenberg-Marquardt. direct (.e. cross) variogram sill parameter (partial sill nugget) becomes negative, fit.variogram called parameter set zero, FALSE flag fit sill. implies search move away search space boundaries. singular model fits: variogram turns flat, horizontal sloping line, fitting three parameter model exponential spherical nugget bit heavy: infinite number possible combinations sill range (large) fit sloping line. case, returned, singular model may still useful: just try plot . Gstat converges parameter values stabilize, may case. Another case singular model fits happens model reaches sill (spherical) fit nugget, range parameter starts, converges value smaller distance second sample variogram estimate. case, , infinite number possibilities occur essentially fitting line single (first sample variogram) point. cases, fixing one variogram model parameters may help . function accept anisotropic sample variograms input. fit model given direction interval sample variogram  includes direction. possible fit  multiple direction model direction sample variogram,  case model fitted average directions.

text: initial parameters model NA, given default values follows. range parameter given one third maximum value object$dist. nugget value given mean value first three values object$gamma.  partial sill given mean last five values object$gamma. Values fit.method 1: weights equal $N_j$; 2: weights equal $N_j/((gamma(h_j))^2)$; 5 (ignore, use fit.variogram.reml); 6: unweighted (OLS); 7: $N_j/(h_j^2)$.  (: http://www.gstat.org/gstat.pdf, table 4.2).

code: library(sp) data(meuse) coordinates(meuse) = ~x+y vgm1 <- variogram(log(zinc)~1, meuse) fit.variogram(vgm1, vgm(1, "Sph", 300, 1)) #>   model      psill  range #> 1   Nug 0.05065547   0.00 #> 2   Sph 0.59060085 896.97 fit.variogram(vgm1, vgm("Sph")) #>   model      psill    range #> 1   Nug 0.05065971   0.0000 #> 2   Sph 0.59060511 897.0011  # optimize the value of kappa in a Matern model, using ugly <<- side effect: f = function(x) attr(m.fit <<- fit.variogram(vgm1, vgm(,"Mat",nugget=NA,kappa=x)),"SSErr") optimize(f, c(0.1, 5)) #> $minimum #> [1] 1.341907 #>  #> $objective #> [1] 1.092713e-05 #>  plot(vgm1, m.fit)  # best fit from the (0.3, 0.4, 0.5. ... , 5) sequence: (m <- fit.variogram(vgm1, vgm("Mat"), fit.kappa = TRUE)) #>   model     psill    range kappa #> 1   Nug 0.0890710   0.0000   0.0 #> 2   Mat 0.5783097 221.5003   1.3 attr(m, "SSErr") #> [1] 1.093181e-05

Computers Geosciences, 30: 683-691. kriging known, varying measurement errors (weights), see e.g. Delhomme, J.P.  Kriging hydrosciences.  Advances Water Resources, 1(5):251-266, 1978; see also section Kriging known measurement errors gstat user's manual, http://www.gstat.org/

title: Create gstat objects, or subset it — gstat
text: Edzer Pebesma

title: Create gstat objects, or subset it — gstat
text: function currently copies data objects gstat object, may become large object. like copy name data frame, get work. help appreciated. Subsetting (see examples) done using id's variables, using numeric subsets. Subsetted gstat objects contain cross variograms () original gstat object contained (ii) order subset indexes increases, numerically, given order gstat object. merge item may seem obscure. Still, colocated cokriging, needed. See texts Goovaerts, Wackernagel, Chiles Delfiner, look standardised ordinary kriging 1992 Deutsch Journel Isaaks Srivastava. cases, two variables share common mean parameter. Gstat generalises case: two variables may share regression coefficients; allowing instance analysis covariance models, variograms left (see e.g. R. Christensen's ``Plane answers'' book linear models). tests directory package contains examples file merge.R. also demo(pcb) merges slopes across years, year-dependent intercept.

title: Create gstat objects, or subset it — gstat
code: library(sp) data(meuse) coordinates(meuse) = ~x+y # let's do some manual fitting of two direct variograms and a cross variogram g <- gstat(id = "ln.zinc", formula = log(zinc)~1, data = meuse) g <- gstat(g, id = "ln.lead", formula = log(lead)~1, data = meuse) # examine variograms and cross variogram: plot(variogram(g))  # enter direct variograms: g <- gstat(g, id = "ln.zinc", model = vgm(.55, "Sph", 900, .05)) g <- gstat(g, id = "ln.lead", model = vgm(.55, "Sph", 900, .05)) # enter cross variogram: g <- gstat(g, id = c("ln.zinc", "ln.lead"), model = vgm(.47, "Sph", 900, .03)) # examine fit: plot(variogram(g), model = g$model, main = "models fitted by eye")  # see also demo(cokriging) for a more efficient approach g["ln.zinc"] #> data: #> ln.zinc : formula = log(zinc)`~`1 ; data dim = 155 x 12 #> variograms: #>            model psill range #> ln.zinc[1]   Nug  0.05     0 #> ln.zinc[2]   Sph  0.55   900 g["ln.lead"] #> data: #> ln.lead : formula = log(lead)`~`1 ; data dim = 155 x 12 #> variograms: #>            model psill range #> ln.lead[1]   Nug  0.05     0 #> ln.lead[2]   Sph  0.55   900 g[c("ln.zinc", "ln.lead")] #> data: #> ln.zinc : formula = log(zinc)`~`1 ; data dim = 155 x 12 #> ln.lead : formula = log(lead)`~`1 ; data dim = 155 x 12 #> variograms: #>                    model psill range #> ln.zinc[1]           Nug  0.05     0 #> ln.zinc[2]           Sph  0.55   900 #> ln.lead[1]           Nug  0.05     0 #> ln.lead[2]           Sph  0.55   900 #> ln.zinc.ln.lead[1]   Nug  0.03     0 #> ln.zinc.ln.lead[2]   Sph  0.47   900 g[1] #> data: #> ln.zinc : formula = log(zinc)`~`1 ; data dim = 155 x 12 #> variograms: #>            model psill range #> ln.zinc[1]   Nug  0.05     0 #> ln.zinc[2]   Sph  0.55   900 g[2] #> data: #> ln.lead : formula = log(lead)`~`1 ; data dim = 155 x 12 #> variograms: #>            model psill range #> ln.lead[1]   Nug  0.05     0 #> ln.lead[2]   Sph  0.55   900  # Inverse distance interpolation with inverse distance power set to .5: # (kriging variants need a variogram model to be specified) data(meuse.grid) gridded(meuse.grid) = ~x+y meuse.gstat <- gstat(id = "zinc", formula = zinc ~ 1, data = meuse,    nmax = 7, set = list(idp = .5)) meuse.gstat #> data: #> zinc : formula = zinc`~`1 ; data dim = 155 x 12 nmax = 7 #> set idp = 0.5;  z <- predict(meuse.gstat, meuse.grid) #> [inverse distance weighted interpolation] spplot(z["zinc.pred"])  # see demo(cokriging) and demo(examples) for further examples,  # and the manuals for predict and image  # local universal kriging gmeuse <- gstat(id = "log_zinc", formula = log(zinc)~sqrt(dist), data = meuse) # variogram of residuals vmeuse.res <- fit.variogram(variogram(gmeuse), vgm(1, "Exp", 300, 1)) # prediction from local neighbourhoods within radius of 170 m or at least 10 points gmeuse <- gstat(id = "log_zinc", formula = log(zinc)~sqrt(dist),   data = meuse, maxdist=170, nmin=10, force=TRUE, model=vmeuse.res) predmeuse <- predict(gmeuse, meuse.grid) #> [using universal kriging] spplot(predmeuse)

title: Image Gridded Coordinates in Data Frame — image
text: image.data.frame plots image gridded data, organized arbritrary order, data frame. uses xyz2img image.default . S-Plus version, xyz2img tries make image object size plot equal aspect ratio; R version, image.data.frame uses asp=1 argument guarantee . xyz2img returns list components: z, matrix containing z-values; x, increasing coordinates rows z; y, increasing coordinates columns z. list suitable input image.default.

title: Image Gridded Coordinates in Data Frame — image
text: wrote function found levelplot, Lattice/Trellis function lets control aspect ratio aspect argument, automatically draws legend, therefore now prefer levelplot image. Plotting points levelplots probably done providing panel function using lpoints. (S-Plus -- ) hard (impossible) get exactly right cell shapes (e.g., square square grid) without altering size plotting region, function tries hard extending image plot either x- y-direction.  larger grid, better approximation. Geographically correct images can obtained modifiying par("pin"). Read examples, image 2 x 2 grid, play par("pin") want learn .

Atteia, O., Dubois, J.-P., Webster, R., 1994, Geostatistical analysis soil contamination Swiss Jura: Environmental Pollution 86, 315-327 Webster, R., Atteia, O., Dubois, J.-P., 1994, Coregionalization trace metals soil Swiss Jura: European Journal Soil Science 45, 205-218

title: Jura data set — jura
text: points data sets obtained http://home.comcast.net/~pgoovaerts/book.html, seems longer available; grid data kindly provided Pierre Goovaerts. following codes used convert prediction.dat validation.dat jura.pred jura.val (see examples ): Rock Types: 1: Argovian, 2: Kimmeridgian, 3: Sequanian, 4: Portlandian, 5: Quaternary. Land uses: 1: Forest, 2: Pasture (Weide(land), Wiese, Grasland), 3: Meadow (Wiese, Flur, Matte, Anger), 4: Tillage (Ackerland, bestelltes Land) Points 22 100 validation set (validation.dat[c(22,100),]) seem lie exactly grid originally intended, kept consistent book. Georeferencing based two control points Swiss grid system shown Figure 1 Atteia et al. (see ) points digitized tentatively georeferenced scanned map. RMSE 2.4 m. Location points field less precise.

code: library(sp) data(meuse) coordinates(meuse) <- ~x+y m <- vgm(.59, "Sph", 874, .04) # five-fold cross validation: x <- krige.cv(log(zinc)~1, meuse, m, nmax = 40, nfold=5) bubble(x, "residual", main = "log(zinc): 5-fold CV residuals")   # multivariable; thanks to M. Rufino: meuse.g <- gstat(id = "zn", formula = log(zinc) ~ 1, data = meuse) meuse.g <- gstat(meuse.g, "cu", log(copper) ~ 1, meuse) meuse.g <- gstat(meuse.g, model = vgm(1, "Sph", 900, 1), fill.all = TRUE) x <- variogram(meuse.g, cutoff = 1000) meuse.fit = fit.lmc(x, meuse.g) out = gstat.cv(meuse.fit, nmax = 40, nfold = 5)  #> Linear Model of Coregionalization found. title: Simple, Ordinary or Universal, global or local, Point or Block Kriging, or simulation. — krige
text: Daniel G. Krige South African scientist mining engineer first used generalised least squares prediction spatial covariances 50's. George Matheron coined term kriging 60's action , although similar approaches taken field meteorology. Beside Krige's name, consider "krige" "kriging" "predict" "prediction".

title: Simple, Ordinary or Universal, global or local, Point or Block Kriging, or simulation. — krige
code: library(sp) data(meuse) coordinates(meuse) = ~x+y data(meuse.grid) gridded(meuse.grid) = ~x+y m <- vgm(.59, "Sph", 874, .04) # ordinary kriging: x <- krige(log(zinc)~1, meuse, meuse.grid, model = m) #> [using ordinary kriging] spplot(x["var1.pred"], main = "ordinary kriging predictions")  spplot(x["var1.var"],  main = "ordinary kriging variance")  # simple kriging: x <- krige(log(zinc)~1, meuse, meuse.grid, model = m, beta = 5.9) #> [using simple kriging] # residual variogram: m <- vgm(.4, "Sph", 954, .06) # universal block kriging: x <- krige(log(zinc)~x+y, meuse, meuse.grid, model = m, block = c(40,40)) #> [using universal kriging] spplot(x["var1.pred"], main = "universal kriging predictions")   # krige0, using user-defined covariance function and multiple responses in y: # exponential variogram with range 500, defined as covariance function: v = function(x, y = x) { exp(-spDists(coordinates(x),coordinates(y))/500) } # krige two variables in a single pass (using 1 covariance model): y = cbind(meuse$zinc,meuse$copper,meuse$lead,meuse$cadmium) x <- krige0(zinc~1, meuse, meuse.grid, v, y = y) meuse.grid$zinc = x[,1] spplot(meuse.grid["zinc"], main = "zinc")  meuse.grid$copper = x[,2] spplot(meuse.grid["copper"], main = "copper")   # the following has NOTHING to do with kriging, but -- # return the median of the nearest 11 observations: x = krige(zinc~1, meuse, meuse.grid, set = list(method = "med"), nmax = 11) #> [median estimation] # get 25%- and 75%-percentiles of nearest 11 obs, as prediction and variance: x = krige(zinc~1, meuse, meuse.grid, nmax = 11,    set = list(method = "med", quantile = 0.25)) #> [0.25-quantile estimation] # get diversity (# of different values) and mode from 11 nearest observations: x = krige(zinc~1, meuse, meuse.grid, nmax = 11, set = list(method = "div")) #> [within-neighbourhood diversity and modus]

title: Ordinary global Spatio-Temporal Kriging — krigeST
code: library(sp) library(spacetime) sumMetricVgm <- vgmST("sumMetric",                       space = vgm( 4.4, "Lin", 196.6,  3),                       time  = vgm( 2.2, "Lin",   1.1,  2),                       joint = vgm(34.6, "Exp", 136.6, 12),                       stAni = 51.7)  data(air) suppressWarnings(proj4string(stations) <- CRS(proj4string(stations))) rural = STFDF(stations, dates, data.frame(PM10 = as.vector(air)))  rr <- rural[,"2005-06-01/2005-06-03"] rr <- as(rr,"STSDF")  x1 <- seq(from=6,to=15,by=1) x2 <- seq(from=48,to=55,by=1)  DE_gridded <- SpatialPoints(cbind(rep(x1,length(x2)), rep(x2,each=length(x1))),                              proj4string=CRS(proj4string(rr@sp))) gridded(DE_gridded) <- TRUE DE_pred <- STF(sp=as(DE_gridded,"SpatialPoints"), time=rr@time) DE_kriged <- krigeST(PM10~1, data=rr, newdata=DE_pred,                      modelList=sumMetricVgm) #> Warning: The spatio-temporal variogram model does not carry the strongly recommended attribute 'temporal unit'. #>  The unit 'days' has been assumed. krigeST could not check whether the temporal distances between locations and in the variogram coincide. gridded(DE_kriged@sp) <- TRUE stplot(DE_kriged)

title: Oxford soil samples — oxford
text: Data: 126 soil augerings 100 x 100m square grid, 6 columns 21 rows. Grid oriented long axis North-north-west South-south-east Origin grid South-south-east point, 100m outside grid. Original data part soil survey carried P.. Burrough 1967. survey area located chalk downlands Berkshire Downs Oxfordshire, UK. Three soil profile units recognised shallow Rendzina soils; Ia - shallow, grey calcareous soils less 40cm deep chalk;  Ct - shallow moderately deep, grey-brown calcareous soils  calcareous colluvium, Cr: deep, moderately acid, red-brown clayey soils.  soil profile classes registered every augering. addition, independent landscape soil map made interpolating soil boundaries soil types, using information changes landform.  soil varies short distances, field mapping caused soil borings receive different classification classification based point data. Also registered auger point site elevation (m), depth solid chalk rock (cm) depth lime cm. Also, percent clay content, Munsell colour components VALUE CHROMA , lime content soil (tested using HCl)  recorded top two soil layers (0-20cm 20-40cm). Samples topsoil taken bulk sample within circle radius 2.5m around sample point used laboratory determination Mg (ppm), OM1 %, CEC mequ/100g air dry soil, pH, P ppm K (ppm).

title: Plot a sample variogram, and possibly a fitted model — plot.gstatVariogram
code: library(sp) data(meuse) coordinates(meuse) = ~x+y vgm1 <- variogram(log(zinc)~1, meuse) plot(vgm1)  model.1 <- fit.variogram(vgm1,vgm(1,"Sph",300,1)) plot(vgm1, model=model.1)  plot(vgm1, plot.numbers = TRUE, pch = "+")  vgm2 <- variogram(log(zinc)~1, meuse, alpha=c(0,45,90,135)) plot(vgm2)  # the following demonstrates plotting of directional models: model.2 <- vgm(.59,"Sph",926,.06,anis=c(0,0.3)) plot(vgm2, model=model.2)    g = gstat(NULL, "zinc < 200", I(zinc<200)~1, meuse) g = gstat(g, "zinc < 400", I(zinc<400)~1, meuse) g = gstat(g, "zinc < 800", I(zinc<800)~1, meuse) # calculate multivariable, directional variogram: v = variogram(g, alpha=c(0,45,90,135)) plot(v, group.id = FALSE, auto.key = TRUE) # id and id pairs panels  plot(v, group.id = TRUE, auto.key = TRUE)  # direction panels   # variogram maps: plot(variogram(g, cutoff=1000, width=100, map=TRUE),     main = "(cross) semivariance maps")  plot(variogram(g, cutoff=1000, width=100, map=TRUE), np=TRUE,     main = "number of point pairs")

text: Edzer Pebesma

title: Multivariable Geostatistical Prediction and Simulation — predict
code: # generate 5 conditional simulations library(sp) data(meuse) coordinates(meuse) = ~x+y v <- variogram(log(zinc)~1, meuse) m <- fit.variogram(v, vgm(1, "Sph", 300, 1)) plot(v, model = m)  set.seed(131) data(meuse.grid) gridded(meuse.grid) = ~x+y sim <- krige(formula = log(zinc)~1, meuse, meuse.grid, model = m,    nmax = 10, beta = 5.9, nsim = 5) # for speed -- 10 is too small!! #> [using conditional Gaussian simulation] # show all 5 simulation spplot(sim)   # calculate generalised least squares residuals w.r.t. constant trend: g <- gstat(NULL, "log.zinc", log(zinc)~1, meuse, model = m) blue0 <- predict(g, newdata = meuse, BLUE = TRUE) #> [generalized least squares trend estimation] blue0$blue.res <- log(meuse$zinc) - blue0$log.zinc.pred bubble(blue0, zcol = "blue.res", main = "GLS residuals w.r.t. constant")   # calculate generalised least squares residuals w.r.t. linear trend: m <- fit.variogram(variogram(log(zinc)~sqrt(dist.m), meuse),    vgm(1, "Sph", 300, 1)) g <- gstat(NULL, "log.zinc", log(zinc)~sqrt(dist.m), meuse, model = m) blue1 <- predict(g, meuse, BLUE = TRUE) #> [generalized least squares trend estimation] blue1$blue.res <- log(meuse$zinc) - blue1$log.zinc.pred bubble(blue1, zcol = "blue.res",    main = "GLS residuals w.r.t. linear trend")   # unconditional simulation on a 100 x 100 grid xy <- expand.grid(1:100, 1:100) names(xy) <- c("x","y") gridded(xy) = ~x+y g.dummy <- gstat(formula = z~1, dummy = TRUE, beta = 0,   model = vgm(1,"Exp",15), nmax = 10) # for speed -- 10 is too small!! yy <- predict(g.dummy, xy, nsim = 4) #> [using unconditional Gaussian simulation] # show one realisation: spplot(yy[1])  # show all four: spplot(yy)

title: Spatial Interpolation Comparison 2004 data set: Natural Ambient Radioactivity — sic2004
text: text copied original sic2004 event, longer online available. variable used SIC 2004 exercise natural ambient radioactivity measured Germany. data, provided kindly German Federal Office Radiation Protection (BfS), gamma dose rates reported means national automatic monitoring network (IMIS). frame SIC2004,  rectangular area used select 1008 monitoring stations (total around 2000 stations). 1008 stations, 11 days measurements randomly selected last 12 months average daily dose rates calculated day. Hence, ended 11 data sets. Prior information (sic.train): 10 data sets 200 points identical concerns locations monitoring stations prepared. locations randomly selected (see Figure 1). data sets differ Z values since set corresponds 1 day measurement made last 14 months. information provided date measurement.  10 data sets (10 days measurements) can used prior information tune parameters mapping algorithms. information provided sets. Participants free course gather information variable literature . 200 monitoring stations randomly taken larger set 1008 stations. remaining 808 monitoring stations topology given sic.pred.  Participants SIC2004 estimate values variable taken 808 locations. SIC2004 data (sic.val, variable dayx): exercise consists using 200 measurements made 11th day (data exercise) estimate values observed remaining 808 locations (hence question marks symbols maps shown Figure 3). measurements provided two weeks (15th September 1st October 2004) web page restricted participants. true values observed 808 locations released end exercise allow participants write manuscripts (sic.test, variables dayx joker). addition, joker data set released (sic.val, variable joker), contains anomaly. anomaly generated simulation model, represent measured levels.

title: Calculate Spatio-Temporal Sample Variogram — variogramST
text: formula formula, specifying dependent variable. locations STFDF STSDF containing variable; kept    compatibility reasons variogram, either locations data    must provided. data STFDF, STSDF STIDF containing variable. ... arguments passed underlying    variogram function. case using data type STIDF, argument tunit recommended (used case STIDF) set temporal unit tlags. Additionally, twindow can passed control temporal window used temporal distance calculations. builds property xts ordered next twindow instances considered. avoids need huge temporal distance matrices. default uses twice number average difference goes temporal cutoff. tlags integer; time lags consider case data class STIDF actual temporal boundaries time unit given tunit otherwise unit diff index time slot generate assumed. cutoff spatial separation distance point pairs included semivariance estimates; default, length diagonal box spanning data divided three. width width subsequent distance intervals data point pairs grouped semivariance estimates, default    cutoff divided 15 equal lags. boundaries numerical vector distance interval upper boundaries;  values strictly increasing progress logical; TRUE, show text progress bar pseudo integer; use pseudo cross variogram computing time-lagged spatial variograms? -1: find coordinates -- equal yes, else ; 0: ; 1: yes. assumeRegular logical; whether time series assumed regular.    first time step assumed representative whole series. Note,   temporal lags considered index, check made whether pairs   actually desired separating distance. na.omit shall NA values spatio-temporal variogram dropped? case complete rows columns variogram consists NA , plot might produce distorted picture. cores number cores use parallel

title: Calculate Spatio-Temporal Sample Variogram — variogramST
text: spatio-temporal sample variogram contains besides fields  np, dist gamma spatio-temporal fields,  timelag, spacelag avgDist, first indicates time lag    used, second third different spatial lags. spacelag midpoint spatial   lag intervals passed parameter boundaries, whereas avgDist average    distance point pairs found distance interval temporal lags (.e.    averages values dist per temporal lag.) compute variograms space lag \(h\)   time lag \(t\), pseudo cross variogram \((Z_i(s)-Z_{+t}(s+h))^2\) averaged time    lagged observation sets \(Z_i\) \(Z_{+t}\) available (weighted number pairs involved).

Read fit.variogram find NA variogram parameters given initial values fitting model, based sample variogram. Package automap gives options automated variogram modelling.

title: Generate, or Add to Variogram Model — vgm
text: Geometric anisotropy can modelled individual simple model giving two five anisotropy parameters, two two-dimensional five three-dimensional data. case, range defined range direction strongest correlation, major range. Anisotropy parameters define direction (main axis), much shorter range () direction(s) perpendicular main axis. two dimensions, two parameters define anisotropy ellipse, say anis = c(30, 0.5). first parameter, 30, refers main axis direction: angle principal direction continuity (measured degrees, clockwise positive Y, .e. North). second parameter, 0.5, anisotropy ratio, ratio minor range major range (value 0 1).  , example, range major direction (North-East) 100, range minor direction (South-East) 0.5 x 100 = 50. three dimensions, five values given form anis = c(p,q,r,s,t).  Now, $p$ angle principal direction continuity (measured degrees, clockwise Y, direction X), $q$ dip angle principal direction continuity (measured positive degrees horizontal), $r$ third rotation angle rotate two minor directions around principal direction defined $p$ $q$. positive angle acts counter-clockwise looking principal direction. Anisotropy ratios $s$ $t$ ratios major range two minor ranges. anisotropy code taken GSLIB. Note http://www.gslib.com/sec_gb.html reported code bug. Quoting site: ``third angle GSLIB programs operates opposite direction specified GSLIB book.  Explanation - books says (pp27) angle measured clockwise looking toward origin (postive principal direction), counter-clockwise. documentation error. Although rarely used, correct specification third angle critical used.'' (Note anis = c(p,s) equivalent anis = c(p,0,0,s,1).) implementation gstat 2D 3D anisotropy taken gslib (probably 1992) code.  seen paper argued 3D anisotropy code implemented gslib (gstat) error, corrected anything afterwards.

title: Generate, or Add to Variogram Model — vgm
code: vgm() #>    short                                      long #> 1    Nug                              Nug (nugget) #> 2    Exp                         Exp (exponential) #> 3    Sph                           Sph (spherical) #> 4    Gau                            Gau (gaussian) #> 5    Exc        Exclass (Exponential class/stable) #> 6    Mat                              Mat (Matern) #> 7    Ste Mat (Matern, M. Stein's parameterization) #> 8    Cir                            Cir (circular) #> 9    Lin                              Lin (linear) #> 10   Bes                              Bes (bessel) #> 11   Pen                      Pen (pentaspherical) #> 12   Per                            Per (periodic) #> 13   Wav                                Wav (wave) #> 14   Hol                                Hol (hole) #> 15   Log                         Log (logarithmic) #> 16   Pow                               Pow (power) #> 17   Spl                              Spl (spline) #> 18   Leg                            Leg (Legendre) #> 19   Err                   Err (Measurement error) #> 20   Int                           Int (Intercept) vgm("Sph") #>   model psill range #> 1   Nug    NA     0 #> 2   Sph    NA    NA vgm(NA, "Sph", NA, NA) #>   model psill range #> 1   Nug    NA     0 #> 2   Sph    NA    NA vgm(, "Sph") # "Sph" is second argument: NO nugget in this case #>   model psill range #> 1   Sph    NA    NA vgm(10, "Exp", 300) #>   model psill range #> 1   Exp    10   300 x <- vgm(10, "Exp", 300) vgm(10, "Nug", 0) #>   model psill range #> 1   Nug    10     0 vgm(10, "Exp", 300, 4.5) #>   model psill range #> 1   Nug   4.5     0 #> 2   Exp  10.0   300 vgm(10, "Mat", 300, 4.5, kappa = 0.7) #>   model psill range kappa #> 1   Nug   4.5     0   0.0 #> 2   Mat  10.0   300   0.7 vgm( 5, "Exp", 300, add.to = vgm(5, "Exp", 60, nugget = 2.5)) #>   model psill range #> 1   Nug   2.5     0 #> 2   Exp   5.0    60 #> 3   Exp   5.0   300 vgm(10, "Exp", 300, anis = c(30, 0.5)) #>   model psill range ang1 anis1 #> 1   Exp    10   300   30   0.5 vgm(10, "Exp", 300, anis = c(30, 10, 0, 0.5, 0.3)) #>   model psill range ang1 ang2 ang3 anis1 anis2 #> 1   Exp    10   300   30   10    0   0.5   0.3 # Matern variogram model: vgm(1, "Mat", 1, kappa=.3) #>   model psill range kappa #> 1   Mat     1     1   0.3 x <- vgm(0.39527463, "Sph", 953.8942, nugget = 0.06105141) x #>   model      psill    range #> 1   Nug 0.06105141   0.0000 #> 2   Sph 0.39527463 953.8942 print(x, digits = 3); #>   model  psill range #> 1   Nug 0.0611     0 #> 2   Sph 0.3953   954 # to see all components, do print.data.frame(x) #>   model      psill    range kappa ang1 ang2 ang3 anis1 anis2 #> 1   Nug 0.06105141   0.0000   0.0    0    0    0     1     1 #> 2   Sph 0.39527463 953.8942   0.5    0    0    0     1     1 vv=vgm(model = "Tab",  covtable =    variogramLine(vgm(1, "Sph", 1), 1, n=1e4, min = 0, covariance = TRUE)) vgm(c("Mat", "Sph")) #> [[1]] #>   model psill range kappa #> 1   Nug    NA     0   0.0 #> 2   Mat    NA    NA   0.5 #>  #> [[2]] #>   model psill range #> 1   Nug    NA     0 #> 2   Sph    NA    NA #>  #> attr(,"class") #> [1] "variogramModelList" "list"               vgm(, c("Mat", "Sph")) # no nugget #> [[1]] #>   model psill range kappa #> 1   Mat    NA    NA   0.5 #>  #> [[2]] #>   model psill range #> 1   Sph    NA    NA #>  #> attr(,"class") #> [1] "variogramModelList" "list"

title: Constructing a spatio-temporal variogram — vgmST
text: Constructs spatio-temporal variogram given type checking minimal set parameters.

title: Constructing a spatio-temporal variogram — vgmST
code: vgmST(stModel, ..., space, time, joint, sill, k, nugget, stAni, temporalUnit)

title: Constructing a spatio-temporal variogram — vgmST
text: stModel string identifying spatio-temporal variogram model (see details ). string optional "_" used identify model. mechanism can used identify different fits model (separable_A separable_B interpreted separable models, carry different names). ... unused, ensure exact match following parameters. space spatial variogram. time temporal variogram. joint joint spatio-temporal variogram. sill joint spatio-temporal sill. k weighting product product-sum model. nugget joint spatio-temporal nugget. stAni spatio-temporal anisotropy; number space units equivalent one time unit. temporalUnit length one character vector, indicating temporal unit (like secs)

title: Constructing a spatio-temporal variogram — vgmST
text: different implemented spatio-temporal variogram models following required parameters (see well example section) separable: variogram space time joint spatio-temporal sill (variograms may separate nugget effect, joint sill 1) generating call productSum: variogram space time , weighting product k generating call sumMetric: variogram (potentially including nugget effect) space, time joint spatio-temporal anisotropy ratio stAni generating call simpleSumMetric: variogram (without nugget effect) space, time joint , joint spatio-temporal nugget effect spatio-temporal anisotropy ratio stAni generating call metric: spatio-temporal joint variogram (potentially including nugget effect) stAni generating call
code: vgmST("separable", space, time, sill) vgmST("productSum", space, time, k) vgmST("sumMetric", space, time, joint, stAni) vgmST("simpleSumMetric", space, time, joint, nugget, stAni) vgmST("metric", joint, stAni)

title: Constructing a spatio-temporal variogram — vgmST
text: Returns S3 object  class StVariogramModel.

title: Constructing a spatio-temporal variogram — vgmST
text: Benedikt Graeler

title: Constructing a spatio-temporal variogram — vgmST
code: # separable model: spatial and temporal sill will be ignored # and kept constant at 1-nugget respectively. A joint sill is used. separableModel <- vgmST("separable",                          space=vgm(0.9,"Exp", 147, 0.1),                         time =vgm(0.9,"Exp", 3.5, 0.1),                         sill=40)  # product sum model: spatial and temporal nugget will be ignored and kept # constant at 0. Only a joint nugget is used. prodSumModel <- vgmST("productSum",                       space=vgm(39, "Sph", 343, 0),                       time= vgm(36, "Exp",   3, 0),                        k=15)  # sum metric model: spatial, temporal and joint nugget will be estimated sumMetricModel <- vgmST("sumMetric",                         space=vgm( 6.9, "Lin", 200, 3.0),                         time =vgm(10.3, "Lin",  15, 3.6),                         joint=vgm(37.2, "Exp",  84,11.7),                         stAni=77.7)                         # simplified sumMetric model, only a overall nugget is fitted. The spatial,  # temporal and jont nuggets are set to 0. simpleSumMetricModel <- vgmST("simpleSumMetric",                               space=vgm(20,"Lin", 150, 0),                               time =vgm(20,"Lin", 10,  0),                               joint=vgm(20,"Exp", 150, 0),                               nugget=1, stAni=15)  # metric model metricModel <- vgmST("metric",                      joint=vgm(60, "Exp", 150, 10),                      stAni=60)

Roche's Point  RPT        51d48'N        8d15'W     6.36 #> 6           Birr  BIR        53d05'N        7d53'W     3.65 #> 7      Mullingar  MUL        53d32'N        7d22'W     4.38 #> 8     Malin Head  MAL        55d22'N        7d20'W     8.03 #> 9       Kilkenny  KIL        52d40'N        7d16'W     3.25 #> 10        Clones  CLO        54d11'N        7d14'W     4.48 #> 11        Dublin  DUB        53d26'N        6d15'W     5.05 #> 12       Roslare  ROS 52d16'56.791"N 6d21'25.056"W     6.00 library(sp) # char2dms wind.loc$y = as.numeric(char2dms(as.character(wind.loc[["Latitude"]]))) wind.loc$x = as.numeric(char2dms(as.character(wind.loc[["Longitude"]]))) coordinates(wind.loc) = ~x+y  if (FALSE) { # fig 1: library(maps) library(mapdata) map("worldHires", xlim = c(-11,-5.4), ylim = c(51,55.5)) points(wind.loc, pch=16) text(coordinates(wind.loc), pos=1, label=wind.loc$Station) }  wind$time = ISOdate(wind$year+1900, wind$month, wind$day) # time series of e.g. Dublin data: plot(DUB~time, wind, type= 'l', ylab = "windspeed (knots)", main = "Dublin")   # fig 2: #wind = wind[!(wind$month == 2 & wind$day == 29),] wind$jday = as.numeric(format(wind$time, '%j')) windsqrt = sqrt(0.5148 * as.matrix(wind[4:15])) Jday = 1:366 windsqrt = windsqrt - mean(windsqrt) daymeans = sapply(split(windsqrt, wind$jday), mean) plot(daymeans ~ Jday) lines(lowess(daymeans ~ Jday, f = 0.1))   # subtract the trend: meanwind = lowess(daymeans ~ Jday, f = 0.1)$y[wind$jday] velocity = apply(windsqrt, 2, function(x) { x - meanwind })  # match order of columns in wind to Code in wind.loc: pts = coordinates(wind.loc[match(names(wind[4:15]), wind.loc$Code),])  # fig 3, but not really yet... dists = spDists(pts, longlat=TRUE) corv = cor(velocity) sel = !(as.vector(dists) == 0) plot(as.vector(corv[sel]) ~ as.vector(dists[sel]),   xlim = c(0,500), ylim = c(.4, 1), xlab = "distance (km.)",    ylab = "correlation")   # plots all points twice, ignores zero distance  # now really get fig 3: ros = rownames(corv) == "ROS" dists.nr = dists[!ros,!ros] corv.nr = corv[!ros,!ros] sel = !(as.vector(dists.nr) == 0) plot(as.vector(corv.nr[sel]) ~ as.vector(dists.nr[sel]), pch = 3,   xlim = c(0,500), ylim = c(.4, 1), xlab = "distance (km.)",    ylab = "correlation")  # add outlier: points(corv[ros,!ros] ~ dists[ros,!ros], pch=16, cex=.5) xdiscr = 1:500 # add correlation model: lines(xdiscr, .968 * exp(- .00134 * xdiscr))
